awd_titl_txt: Cyber Pro: Developing Rigorous and Enhanced Academic Modules (DREAMs)
awd_abstract_narration:
Keeping computers and information systems secure is a major challenge. Business, industry, and government need well-prepared technicians who can prevent, detect, and investigate cybersecurity breaches, and the growth of cyber-threats has created a need for many more workers who have appropriate, specific knowledge and skills. In this project, Clark State Community College will work with high schools to engage students in considering this high-demand career field. In particular, the investigators will lead the development of approximately 30 hands-on cybersecurity laboratory modules that are specifically designed for delivery within a high school classroom environment, with its typical time constraints and limited technical resources. The module development process will consider appropriate content, timing, methods of delivery, and incremental development of knowledge and skills. Project teams consisting of college faculty and students and high school teachers and students will design, develop, and test the modules.

The lab modules will cover entry-level cybersecurity knowledge and skills that map to in-demand industry certifications (specifically, CompTIA Security+ and CISSP), and the modules will also be mapped to the National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. Existing high-quality materials will be adapted when possible, and the investigators will coordinate with others who are currently developing cybersecurity curricula to avoid duplications. An advisory board consisting of college, high school, business, military, and government experts will provide guidance on the topics, content, coverage, and flow of the modules. Each module will consist (typically) of a set of PowerPoint slides, a list of Internet references, a written lab activity, assessment questions, application software, and a mapping to industry certifications and the NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework. For each content area, a beginning, intermediate, and advanced cybersecurity lab activity will be developed. The cybersecurity modules will be initially distributed and beta-tested through a hands-on training institute for college and high school educators during the summer.

por.por_cntn:
The NSF (#1700566) DREAMs (Developing Rigorous and Enhanced Academic Modules) grant encompassed three main goals:

  • Goal 1: Develop cybersecurity lab activities that are functional for high school schedules, and can also be used in other college classrooms.
  • Goal 2: Train teachers to implement the modularized activities in their classrooms.
  • Goal 3: Increase accessibility of cybersecurity credentials.

 

Project Outcomes:

Goal #1: Ten cyber security topics were identified. Course content of learning materials, lab, Power Point slides, assessments and Virtual Machines were designed and created. Per the goal of the grant, these learning materials were designed and constructed to be taught in a typical fifty-minute high school time block. These topics were further divided by level of difficulty: Level #1: the students ?See? the topic (could be used as a teacher demo), Level #2: the students ?Do? (Hands on lab), and Level 3: the students must ?critically think? while performing an advanced lab). The idea was to give the instructors a ?complete package? of courseware.

Goal #2: At the conclusion of this grant, high school instructors from multiple states have participated in several workshops (both virtually and in person). In these workshops, the instructors learned cyber security concepts and how these concepts could be integrated into a single class or be constructed to form a complete course.

Goal #3: During the grant conception and design (over 5 years ago), the concept and use of ?digital badging? could be a way to demonstrate cyber security related achievements. Over the course of this grant, our external evaluators and the grant team revisited this goal on several occasions with our stakeholders. Based on these ongoing discussions, it became clear the original goal of digital badging did not have the merit or value it once held. As such, this goal ultimately was not pursued.

 

Two very large hurdles encountered during the grant were two years of COVID restrictions (which necessitated requesting grant extensions), and the passing of the original grant PI.

All courseware developed has been disseminated to Clark.Center and to NYcTE and all workshop participants.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 11/11/2022
Modified by: Gregory Teets
